title: Lumbar Region
raw_text:
For Non-specific low-back pain

Where is your pain located?

Lower back only

Radiates down one leg		(Rule out sciatica)

Radiates down both legs		(Rule out cauda equina syndrome)

How did the pain begin?

Sudden				(Rule out lumbar disc herniation)

Gradual

How long have you been experiencing the pain?

Less than 1 week

1-4 weeks

1-3 months

More than 3 months

What currently aggravates your pain?

Sitting

Standing		(Rule out facet joint syndrome)

Walking

Lifting heavy objects

What makes your pain better?

Resting

Changing positions

Exercise

Pain medications

Do you experience any numbness or tingling sensation in your legs or feet?

Yes	(Rule out lumbar disc herniation or cauda equina syndrome)

No

Have you experienced any weakness in your legs?

Yes		(Rule out cauda equina)

No

Have you had any recent trauma or injury to your lower back?

Yes

No

Have you had any previous episodes of low-back pain?

Yes	(Recurrent low-back pain)

No

Are you experiencing any bowel or bladder dysfunction, such as difficulty or loss of control in urination or defecation?

Yes		(Rule out cauda equina syndrome)

No	

Have you had any recent fever, chills, or other signs of infection?

Yes		(Rule out ankylosing spondylitis or bone tumours and infection)

No

Have you had any recent unintended weight loss?

Yes		(Rule out cancers/infection)

No

TEST:

Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise): Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

Bragard Test: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.



For Sciatica

Do you experience paraesthesia or abnormal sensation in the affected leg?

Yes

No

Does your job or daily tasks involve adopting physically awkward positions?

Yes

No

Do you experience muscle weakness in the affected leg?

Yes

No

Is the pain worsened with flexion of the spine, twisting, bending and/or coughing?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain when elevating the heel or tip-toeing?

Yes

No

Have you had a previous surgical procedure and/or injection recently?

Yes

No

Observation

Check if knee jerk reflex is present

Check if ankle jerk reflex is present

TESTS

Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise): Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

Bragard Test: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign): This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica. 



For Lumbar spinal stenosis

Is the pain you feel aggravated by prolonged walking, standing and lumbar extension?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain radiating to the buttocks, thigh and legs after walking a certain distance?

Yes

No

Is the numbness you feel over the entire leg?

Yes

No

Is the pain you feel relieved by forward flexion (bending forward)?

Yes

No

Do you find walking upstairs easier than walking downstairs?

Yes

No

Do you experience any form of erectile dysfunction?

Yes

No

Is tenderness present at the lumbar, paraspinal or gluteal region?

Yes

No

Observations

Check if a wide-based gait is present

Check if Trendenlenburg’s sign is present

Check for negative romberg test

Check if Achilles tendon reflex is diminished

TEST

Bicycle Stress Test: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

Two-stage Treadmill Test: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.







For Lumbar Disc Herniation

Age (Below 40)

Was the pain onset immediately after a heavy lifting?

Yes

No

Does your job or daily task involve long sitting with lateral bending and rotation?

Yes

No

Do your symptoms feel better when lying supine with your hips and knees flexed?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain radiating to buttock and leg?

Yes

No

If yes, does this pain get worse with sitting and relieved with standing?

Yes

No



Observations

Check for tenderness in the paraspinal musculature

Check for spasms in the paraspinal musculature

Check for decreased reflexes: patellar and ankle jerk

Check for trendenenburg’s sign

TESTS:

Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise): Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

Bragard Test: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign): This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica. 

Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (Wasserman sign): Patient is in prone position, knee is flexed and hip is extended. Reproduction of pain in anterior thigh is positive. 

Kernig Test: Patient’s neck is flexed, hip flexed and the leg is extended. Pain is reproduced in this position.

Milgram Test: pain is reproduced on straight leg elevation for 30 seconds.

Radiographic confirmation:

MRI test.



For Cauda Equina Syndrome

Do you experience pain radiating to both legs?

Yes

No

Do you have a previous history of tumors or trauma to lower back?

Yes

No

Do you experience reduced sensation around your perineal (around genitals) region?

Yes

No

Do you experience reduced sensation in the region of your inner thighs (groin)?

Yes

No

Have you just undergone a lumbar spinal surgery?

Yes

No

Do you find it difficult to initiate urination or experience urinary retention (inability to empty the bladder completely)?

Yes

No

Do you experience bowel incontinence and/or constipation?

Yes

No

Do you experience reduced sexual sensations?

Yes

No

Observation

Check for babinski sign and clonus to rule out upper motor neuron involvement

TEST

Radiographic confirmation

MRI test



For Axial spondyloarthropathy (ankylosing spondylitis)

Age (common in teens and early adults)

Sex (common in male, 3:1)

Do you have a family history of ankylosing spondylitis or any other autoimmune diseases?

Yes

No

Is the pain worse at night and early morning?

Yes

No

Does exercise and physical activity relieve the pain?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain and stiffness in your hips and/or buttocks?

Yes

No

Do exercises and physical activity reduce the associated stiffness?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain and stiffness in your neck or upper back?

Yes

No

Do you experience fatigue, difficulty sleeping and/or general feelings of unwellness?

Yes

No

Do you experience chest pain or discomfort, especially when you take deep breaths?

Yes

No

Have you experienced any symptoms such as red, scaly patches on your skin that may be accompanied by itching or discomfort (psoriasis)?

Yes		(psoriartic ankylosing spondylitis)

No

Have you experienced changes in your posture, such as stooping or hunching forward (question mark sign)?

Yes

No

Have you had any instances of eye inflammation or redness, or increased sensitivity to light (uveitis)?

Yes

No





TEST

Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)

The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion). The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

Modified Schrober’s test: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.

Occiput to wall distance- Normally is 0

Tragus to wall distance- Normally is < 15cm

Intermalleolar distance- Normally >100 cm

Confirmatory test through laboratory investigations.
